timeline.event: Security researcher Shaheen Fazim discovers the use-after-free vulnerability in Chrome CSS engine and reports to Google
Google releases Chrome Stable Channel Update with fix: 145.0.7632.75/76 for Windows/macOS, 144.0.7559.75 for Linux
Google confirms active in-the-wild exploitation; multiple security outlets publish advisories
Hong Kong Computer Emergency Response Team (HKCERT) issues alert to users about the vulnerability

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical zero-day vulnerability was discovered in Google Chrome's CSS rendering engine. The flaw is a use-after-free bug, where Chrome accidentally uses memory that has already been freed, allowing attackers to hijack the browser's execution. Google confirmed that attackers were already exploiting this vulnerability in real-world attacks before the patch was available. This is the first Chrome zero-day exploited in the wild in 2026, and it affects all Chromium-based browsers including Microsoft Edge, Brave, Opera, and Vivaldi.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Anyone using Google Chrome or any Chromium-based browser (Microsoft Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi) on Windows, macOS, or Linux is potentially vulnerable. With Chrome holding approximately 65% of the global browser market share, this affects billions of users worldwide. Organizations that rely on web-based applications and have not yet updated their browsers are at particular risk.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attackers create a specially crafted malicious webpage containing CSS code designed to trigger the use-after-free condition in Chrome's rendering engine. Step 2: The victim visits the malicious page through a phishing link, malicious advertisement, or compromised legitimate website (drive-by attack). Step 3: The crafted CSS causes Chrome to free a memory object but then attempt to reference it again, creating a dangling pointer. Step 4: Attackers reallocate the freed memory with malicious data, redirecting Chrome's execution flow to attacker-controlled code. Step 5: Arbitrary code executes inside Chrome's sandbox, enabling credential theft, session hijacking, malware delivery, or chaining with a sandbox escape for full system compromise.
what_you_should_do: Immediately update Google Chrome to version 145.0.7632.75 or later (Menu > Help > About Google Chrome)
Update all Chromium-based browsers (Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi) to their latest versions
Restart browsers after updating to ensure the patch takes effect
Enforce browser version policies via group policy or MDM in enterprise environments
Educate users about phishing risks and suspicious links until all browsers are patched
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Chrome is the world's most widely used browser with billions of active users. A use-after-free vulnerability in the CSS engine is extremely dangerous because CSS is processed on virtually every webpage, meaning exploitation requires no special user action beyond visiting a malicious page. The confirmed in-the-wild exploitation means attackers have already weaponized this flaw. While the exploit runs inside Chrome's sandbox, it can still steal credentials, hijack sessions, and serve as the first stage of a more destructive attack chain when combined with a sandbox escape.

tactics.description: Attackers host or inject malicious CSS into webpages to exploit the use-after-free vulnerability when victims browse to the page
The use-after-free in CSS processing allows execution of arbitrary code within Chrome's renderer process sandbox
In-sandbox code execution can access session cookies and authentication tokens from the browser process
Attackers leverage the in-sandbox execution to intercept and manipulate browser sessions for credential theft

detection_guidance.summary: The primary defense is ensuring all Chrome and Chromium-based browsers are updated. Monitor browser versions across your environment and watch for signs of exploitation including unusual renderer process behavior.

log_sources.description: Track Chrome versions across all endpoints to identify unpatched browsers; any version before 145.0.7632.75 is vulnerable
Monitor for access to known malicious domains or suspicious redirects that may deliver the exploit
Monitor Chrome renderer process for unusual child process spawning or memory access patterns

what_to_look_for.indicator: Chrome version below 145.0.7632.75 on any endpoint
what_to_look_for.description: Unpatched browsers are vulnerable to this actively exploited zero-day

what_to_look_for.indicator: Unexpected child processes spawned by Chrome renderer
what_to_look_for.description: Successful exploitation may result in the Chrome renderer process spawning unexpected child processes
what_to_look_for.log_field: parent_process='chrome.exe' AND process_type='renderer' AND child_process NOT IN expected_list

what_to_look_for.indicator: Anomalous memory allocation patterns in Chrome CSS processing
what_to_look_for.description: Use-after-free exploitation creates abnormal memory allocation and deallocation patterns in the renderer

immediate_actions.description: Update Google Chrome to 145.0.7632.75/76 on Windows/macOS or 144.0.7559.75 on Linux. Restart browser after update.
Ensure Microsoft Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi and other Chromium-based browsers receive their corresponding security updates
Use group policy or MDM to enforce minimum browser version requirements and block outdated versions from accessing corporate resources
Alert users about increased risk from malicious links and drive-by exploits while unpatched browsers remain in the environment
